abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Global Development
            Learning Network Project for Indonesia were as follows:
            outcomes were unsatisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was substantial, the Bank performance was
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the Bank should
            put clients in the driver's seat when designing
            projects. Client's concerns were obviously unheeded
            during the design stage which led to the subsequent mismatch
            between technology chosen by the Information Solutions Group
            (ISG) and country's technology environment. The idea of
            one-size-fits-all for the entire world, even for technology,
            did not work. In projects such as this, Bank management
            should closely monitor the implementation of the project and
            should move as quickly as possible to re-structure and
            re-design the project when it was evident that the original
            design did not work. Multi-year delays should not be
            considered acceptable and if necessary, such delays should
            be reason enough to call for a redesign, re-appraisal, or
            cancellation of the project. Consensus building is critical
            to effective project design, preparation and implementation.
            When host universities change rectors or other key
            decision-makers, delays can be expected since university
            objectives and programs may be reviewed and priorities
            adjusted to reflect the new administrations views. The
            joining of national and international networks can
            strengthen the potential sustainability of individual
            distance learning centers and provide increased access to programming.
